definition: street stall with goods laid out on the ground
-ly/structural particle: used before a verb or adjective, linking it to preceding modifying adverbial adjunct
lit. to set up a stall on the ground/fig. to start up a new business

sentences.english: There happened to be a shoe stall on the way calling my attention.
sentences.chinese: 路上剛好有家賣鞋子的地攤引起我的注意。

sentences.english: Where is Kunming fit to set up a stall?
Dad didn't regard to his face, set up the street across the street in my school.
sentences.chinese: 爸爸也沒顧得他的面子，在我學校對街擺起了地攤。

sentences.english: By the time police arrived, Herchenrider was laying on his bedroom floor covered in blood.
sentences.chinese: 警方抵達時，赫琛瑞德躺在地攤上，身上都是血。

sentences.english: Tai Hao finds the sinister gang in the market, placed a ground to spread out permissibly with Zhong Dou.
sentences.chinese: 泰浩找到市場裏的黑幫，和鍾鬥獲准擺起了一個地攤。

sentences.english: Stalls, when setting up, would cause pollution to the environment.
sentences.chinese: 擺地攤過程中會給環境造成污染。

sentences.english: Have you seen the award-winning actor in the street sets up a stall?
sentences.chinese: 你可曾看到金馬獎影帝在街邊擺地攤？

sentences.english: Did you ever see golden horse awards for best actor in street put stall in?
sentences.chinese: 你可曾看到金馬獎影帝在街邊擺地攤？

sentences.english: There are lots of stalls on my way home.
sentences.chinese: 我回家的路上總是佈滿了地攤。

sentences.english: If his home is better, who would put stall in the cold night.
sentences.chinese: 家境哪怕好一點，誰會大冷天夜裏擺地攤。

definition: to set up a vendor's stall in the street
to sell/to betray/to spare no effort/to show off or flaunt
top of streets, bottom of alleys (idiom); everywhere in the city
to look in all directions (idiom)/to glance around
